text: <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells from active RA patients are characterized by their resistance to <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> inhibition of <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production , due to constitutive <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> phosphorylation and impaired <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation .

The defective <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling is possibly associated with <extra_id_0> SOCS1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> predominance over <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
These abnormalities in active RA are thought to be induced mainly after chronic exposure to high concentrations of <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

The limited efficacy of <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> treatment of RA patients [ 50 ] may be explained in part by the unresponsiveness to <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> of inflammatory cells , including T cells .

On the contrary , the therapeutic efficacy of anti - <extra_id_0> IL-6 receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> antibody has been reported in RA patients [ 51 ] , and one of the effects of this therapy may be to normalize T cells through the inhibition of <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - dependent <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation .

More specific therapy targeting <extra_id_0> STAT3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation will be awaited ; for example , the induction of the <extra_id_0> SOCS3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene , the efficacy of which has been demonstrated in animal models [ 37 ] .
